title: 107_s1686
content: The Act titled "Safe Nursing and Patient Care Act of 2001" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 contains findings related to the Act. The Congress finds that higher nurse staffing levels lead to better patient outcomes, but there are challenges in recruiting and retaining nursing staff. Providers are facing challenges in recruiting and retaining nursing staff, with approximately 500,000 licensed nurses not practicing. Job dissatisfaction and mandatory overtime are causing nurses to leave the profession. Mandatory overtime for nurses in the United States contributes to fatigue, medical errors, and compromises patient safety. Limiting mandatory overtime will ensure public safety, quality healthcare services, and aid in nurse retention and recruitment. SEC. 3. LIMITATIONS ON MANDATORY OVERTIME FOR NURSES. Provider Agreements under the Social Security Act are amended to include compliance with limitations on mandatory overtime for nurses. Provider Agreements under the Social Security Act are amended to include limitations on mandatory overtime for nurses, prohibiting providers from requiring nurses to work beyond their scheduled shifts or duty periods. Providers are prohibited from requiring nurses to work beyond scheduled shifts or duty periods, with limitations of 12 hours in a 24-hour period and 80 hours in a consecutive 14-day period. Exceptions apply during declared states of emergency. During a declared state of emergency, providers of services may request nurses to work beyond the usual limitations of 12 hours in a 24-hour period and 80 hours in a consecutive 14-day period to provide an exceptional level of emergency or medical services to the community. During a state of emergency, nurses can be asked to work longer hours if the provider has tried other options and the work requirement ends when the emergency does. During a state of emergency, nurses can file complaints against a provider if they violate work hour limits set by the emergency declaration. During a state of emergency, nurses have the right to report violations of work hour limits by providers, and the Secretary will investigate complaints filed by nurses. The Secretary will investigate complaints of violations filed by nurses, and if a provider is found to have violated the provisions, they must establish a plan of action to correct it and may face civil penalties. The Secretary will require providers to establish a plan of action to address violations and may impose civil penalties. Nurses are protected from discrimination for refusing mandatory overtime. Nurses are protected from discrimination for refusing mandatory overtime and can report violations to regulatory agencies or management personnel. Protected nurses can report violations to regulatory agencies, private accreditation bodies, or management personnel. They can also participate in investigations or proceedings related to the violations and discuss with other employees. Protected nurses can report violations to regulatory agencies, private accreditation bodies, or discuss violations with other employees. Providers of services cannot retaliate against nurses for reporting violations. A nurse cannot be retaliated against for refusing to work mandatory overtime, and is protected when reporting violations in good faith. Nurses must believe reported information is true and that a violation has occurred or may occur. Providers of services must post a notice specifying nurses' rights, including the right to file a complaint. Providers of services must post a sign specifying nurses' rights, including the right to file a complaint with the Secretary against violations. Additionally, nurse schedules must be regularly posted in a conspicuous manner. Providers of services must post nurse schedules in a conspicuous manner and make them available to nurses upon request. The Secretary may impose a civil money penalty for violations. The Secretary may impose a civil money penalty of up to $10,000 for each knowing violation of nurse schedule posting requirements by providers of services. More severe penalties can be imposed for providers with patterns of violations. The Secretary can impose higher civil money penalties on providers who repeatedly violate nurse schedule posting requirements. The penalties will be administered in a similar manner as penalties under section 1128A. The Secretary can impose civil money penalties on providers for violations, with details published online. The Secretary can impose civil money penalties on providers for violations, with details published online, including penalties imposed on providers under previous ownership not being published after a 1-year period. The Secretary can impose civil money penalties on providers for violations, with details published online, including penalties imposed on providers under previous ownership not being published after a 1-year period. Nurses can voluntarily work more than specified hours as long as it aligns with safe patient care standards. Mandatory overtime is defined as hours worked exceeding specified limits. The term 'mandatory overtime' is defined as hours worked exceeding specified limits, requested by a provider of services to a nurse, with potential adverse employment consequences if refused. The term 'nurse' refers to a registered nurse or a licensed practical nurse, and 'provider of services' includes hospitals. Overtime is defined as time worked beyond specified limits. The term 'nurse' includes registered nurses and licensed practical nurses. The term 'provider of services' encompasses various healthcare facilities such as hospitals, outpatient departments, critical access hospitals, ambulatory surgical centers, home health agencies, rehabilitation agencies, and clinics including rural health clinics. The term 'declared state of emergency' refers to an officially designated state of emergency declared by the Federal Government or the head of the appropriate State or local governmental agency. The term 'declared state of emergency' refers to an officially designated state of emergency declared by the Federal Government or the head of the appropriate State or local governmental agency, excluding emergencies resulting from labor disputes in the health care industry or consistent understaffing. The term 'standards of safe patient care' refers to recognized professional standards for nurses. The amendments will take effect 1 year after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. REPORTS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study to establish safe working hour standards for nurses providing patient care, considering various factors. The Secretary will conduct a study to determine safe working hour standards for nurses, with recommendations for maximum work hours to be submitted to Congress within 2 years. Additionally, a report on mandatory overtime in federally operated medical facilities will be provided. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will conduct a study on overtime requirements for nurses in federally operated medical facilities to determine compliance with the Social Security Act. Recommendations for appropriate work hour standards will be included in the report. Medical facilities have practices and policies regarding overtime requirements for nurses that do not align with section 1866(j) of the Social Security Act. Federally operated medical facilities include acute care hospitals, clinics, and home health care clinics run by the Department of Veterans Affairs, Department of Defense, or other agencies. Federally operated medical facilities, including hospitals, clinics, and home health care clinics, are run by the Department of Veterans Affairs, Department of Defense, or other US agencies. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must submit a report to Congress within 6 months of this Act's enactment, with recommendations for policy implementation. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must submit a report to Congress with recommendations for implementing policies on overtime requirements for nurses in federally operated medical facilities, in line with section 1866(j) of the Act.
